On this page

What is this project about? ​

Project Scope: PiKube Kubernetes Service ​

The primary goal of this project is the creation of a home-based Kubernetes cluster using ARM bare metal nodes, specifically Raspberry Pis and Orange Pis. Emphasis is placed on automation of deployment and configuration, leveraging Infrastructure as Code (IaC) and GitOps approaches. This is achieved with the help of tools like Ansible, cloud-init, and Argo CD.

The project incorporates several critical services within the Kubernetes ecosystem, including:

  • Distributed Block Storage: for POD's persistent volumes via LongHorn.
  • Backup and Restore Solution: for the cluster using Velero and Restic.
  • Service Mesh Architecture: facilitated by Linkerd.
  • Observability Platform: encompassing a metrics monitoring solution with Prometheus, a logging and analytics solution via the EFK+LG stack (Elasticsearch-Fluentd/Fluentbit-Kibana + Loki-Grafana), and a distributed tracing solution through Tempo.

In addition to these services, the project project scope encompasses tools and services pivotal for exploring and understanding microservices architectures:

  • Service Mesh Architecture with Linkerd: This tool enhances service interactions, making them more secure, observable, and reliable without altering application code.

  • API Security: Utilizing OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect, alongside an IAM solution like Keycloak, ensures secure and authorized access across our services.

  • Streaming with Kafka: Kafka supports real-time data streaming and inter-service communication, crucial for dynamic microservices environments.

Design Principles ​

  • ARM Bare Metal Nodes: Integration of Raspberry PI and Orange Pis nodes (ARM) within the same cluster.
  • Lightweight Kubernetes Distribution: Adoption of K3S, suitable for Raspberry PI nodes due to its reduced memory requirements.
  • Distributed Block Storage Technology: Preference for Kubernetes distributed storage solutions like Rook/Ceph or Longhorn, with recent ARM 64-bit support.
  • Commitment to Open Source: Utilization of projects under the CNCF: Cloud Native Computing Foundation.
  • Latest Versions for Exploration: Utilizing the latest versions of each open-source project to explore cutting-edge Kubernetes capabilities.
  • Deployment Automation: Using cloud-init for initial OS setup.
  • Configuration Automation: Using Ansible for automating the configuration of cluster nodes, Kubernetes and external service installation, and initiation of cluster bootstrap.
  • Application Provisioning with Argo CD: Applying Argo CD for seamless Kubernetes application provisioning from a Git repository.

Open Source Technologies: Building the Cluster ​

The image below presents a comprehensive view of the open-source technologies utilized in constructing the cluster:

Technology StackDescription
OBSERVABILITY
GrafanaMonitoring Dashboards.
KibanaLogs Analytics Dashboards.
ElasticsearchLogs Analytics.
TempoDistributed Tracing Monitoring.
PrometheusMetrics Monitoring and Alerting.
FluentdLogs Forwarding and Distribution.
FluentbitLogs Collection.
LokiLogs Aggregation.
AUTOMATION
AnsibleStreamlines system configuration, external service integration, and k3s cluster setup.
ArgoCDDeploys Kubernetes applications following GitOps principles.
Cloud-initAutomates the initial configuration and setup of operating systems.
AUTHENTICATION
KeycloakOpen-source Identity and Access Management solution for modern applications and services.
OAuth2.0 ProxyA reverse proxy and static file server that provides authentication using providers like Keycloak, Google, and others.
ORCHESTRATION
K3SA simplified and lightweight Kubernetes distribution.
containerdK3S-integrated runtime for container management.
SECURITY
Cert-managerManages TLS certificates for Kubernetes.
Hashicorp VaultSecures, stores, and tightly controls access to tokens, passwords, certificates, and other sensitive secrets in modern computing.
External Secrets OperatorSynchronizes secrets from external APIs like Hashicorp Vault into Kubernetes.
STORAGE
LonghornDistributed storage solution for Kubernetes, ensuring data persistence.
MinioEfficient S3-compatible object storage system.
NETWORK
CoreDNSProvides DNS services within the Kubernetes environment.
FlannelNetwork interface for Kubernetes, integrated with K3S.
HA ProxyLoad balancer for high availability in Kubernetes API.
Metal LBBare metal load-balancing solution for Kubernetes.
Ingress NGINXManages external access to the services in a Kubernetes cluster.
TraefikAlternative Ingress Controller for Kubernetes, providing HTTP routing and load balancing.
LinkerdProvides a service mesh for Kubernetes, enhancing network communication.
BACKUP
VeleroOffers backup and restore functionalities for Kubernetes clusters, ensuring data protection.
ResticSecure and efficient backup solution, capable of managing file-level backups.

Required External Services and Resources ​

This section outlines necessary external services and resources for the homelab setup. While the primary goal is to host services within the Kubernetes cluster, certain external resources are essential.

Cloud-Based External Services ​

📌 Note

The use of these external resources is optional. The homelab can function without them, but it will lack verified TLS certificates.

Service ProviderEssential ResourcesStrategic Importance
SECURITY
Let's EncryptTLS Certificate AuthorityIssuing verified TLS certificates for secure web communications.
CloudflareWeb Security & CDNProvides DDoS mitigation and performance enhancement via CDN.

Alternative Approaches for Certificate Management and DNS Configuration ​

Option 1: Implementing a Private PKI:

  • Description: A private Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) can be set up to sign TLS certificates internally.
  • Implementation Status: This option is currently feasible with only minimal adjustments necessary.
  • Reference: For detailed implementation steps, refer to the "Quick Start" guide in the documentation.

Option 2: Utilizing Alternative DNS Providers:

  • Context: Cert-manager or Certbot, which are tools for automatic certificate acquisition from Let's Encrypt, can be adapted for use with various DNS providers.
  • Adaptation Requirements: Modifying the deployment approach of the cert-manager application is necessary. This involves integrating new DNS providers and possibly adding additional webhooks or plugins.
  • Current Configuration: Presently, the system is configured with the ACME issuer (specifically Let's Encrypt) using Cloudflare as the DNS-01 challenge provider.
  • Further Information: For a comprehensive list of DNS01 challenge providers compatible with this setup, please consult the cert-manager documentation regarding supported DNS01 providers.

Externally Hosted Services ​

This section outlines specific services hosted outside the Kubernetes cluster. The decision to self-host these services has been made for various strategic reasons.

Service Overview ​

Technology StackStrategic Importance
STRATEGIC SERVICES
MinioS3 Object Store.
Hashicorp VaultSecrets Management.

Minio:

  • Hosting Environment: Initially deployed on a BlueBerry Node, with plans for future migration to a Virtual Machine.
  • Location: Presently operating within local infrastructure, with a roadmap to transition to Azure or Oracle Cloud Infrastructure's Free Tier.
  • Function: Provides an S3-compatible object storage solution for backing up cluster data.

Hashicorp Vault:

  • Hosting Environment: Gateway Node
  • Location: Local Infrastructure
  • Function: Manages and secures access to sensitive data and secrets. It is locally hosted due to its requirement for direct access to the Kubernetes API, making it unsuitable for public cloud hosting. These services are integral to the cluster's functionality, offering essential data backup and secure secrets management solutions.
